items.title: How to expand small square input box on hitting search icon in css?
items.body:
I have a search-bar with search icon at the extreme left as shown here in the fiddle and in the screenshot below.

The HTML and CSS codes which I have used in order to make the search icon is:

HTML:

<div class="nav-top-searchbar">
    <form>
        <span class="fa fa-search searchicon fa-lg" aria-hidden="true"></span>
        <input type="text" name="search">
        <div style="">
            <img tabindex="1" src="https://s9.postimg.org/d6s4xvykv/Ellipsis.png" id="ellipsis">
            <div class="dropdown">
                <li><a href="#">View Status</a><i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i></li>
                <li><a href="#">Release Bills</a></li>
                <li><a href="#">Add Attendee</a></li>
                <li><a href="#">Export as</a></li>
                <li><a href="#">View in Google Sheets</a></li>
                <li><a href="#">Send Notifications</a></li>
            </div>
        </div>


    </form>
</div>

CSS:

.searchicon {
    float: left;
    margin-top: -20px;
    position: relative;
    top: 26px;
    left: 8px;
    color: white;
    border: 1px solid #FFFFFF;
    z-index: 2;
    padding: 3px;
}

Problem Statement:

If I hit on the search-icon, the small square input box (marked by an arrow in the screenshot) surrounding the search icon should expand similar to here.

I am wondering what changes do I need to make in the HTML and CSS codes above or do I need to add any JS code so that if I hit on the search icon it should work in the way as shown here. I tried including the CSS codes from there but for some reasons it didn't work.

items.title: Webpack + React + Typescript
items.body:
Is it possible to use webpack with React and Typescript and be able to bundle those into a web bundle, but still be able to debug original TypeScript and React code? In webpack I'm using ts-loader and ts-jsx-loader plus devtool: "source-map", but when I try to do browser debugging, I can't see original ts code but instead I see code which has been changed by webpack.

My current basic webpack.config.js file:

var webpack = require('webpack');
module.exports = {
  entry: ['./app/main.ts'],
  output: {
    path: './build',
    filename: 'bundle.js'
  },
  debug: true,
  devtool: 'source-map',
  plugins: [
    new webpack.optimize.DedupePlugin(),
    new webpack.optimize.UglifyJsPlugin()
  ],
  resolve: {
    extensions: ['', '.ts', '.js']
  },
  module: {
    loaders: [
      {
        test: /\.ts$/,
        loader: 'ts-loader!ts-jsx-loader'
      }
    ]
  }
};

tsconfig.json:

{
    "compileOnSave": false,
    "version": "1.5.0-alpha",
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "es5",
        "module": "commonjs",
        "noLib": false,
        "sourceMap": true,
        "noImplicitAny": true,
        "removeComments": true
    },
    "files": [
        "./AppComponent.ts",
        "./libs/jsx.d.ts",
        "./libs/react.d.ts",
        "./libs/webpack-runtime.d.ts",
        "./main.ts"
    ]
}

For example - my oryginal .ts file looks like:

import React = require('react');

class AppComponent extends React.Component<any, any> {
  render () {
    return React.jsx(`
      <h1>He world!</h1>
    `);
  }
};
export = AppComponent;

and in chrome debugger it looks like this:

var __extends = this.__extends || function (d, b) {
    for (var p in b) if (b.hasOwnProperty(p)) d[p] = b[p];
    function __() { this.constructor = d; }
    __.prototype = b.prototype;
    d.prototype = new __();
};
var React = __webpack_require__(2);
var AppComponent = (function (_super) {
    __extends(AppComponent, _super);
    function AppComponent() {
        _super.apply(this, arguments);
    }
    AppComponent.prototype.render = function () {
        return (React.createElement("h1", null, "He world!"));
    };
    return AppComponent;
})(React.Component);
;
module.exports = AppComponent;


/*****************
 ** WEBPACK FOOTER
 ** ./app/AppComponent.ts
 ** module id = 158
 ** module chunks = 0
 **/

         var screenSaver = {};


function startScreenSaver(options) {

  //* attach event listeners to exit screensaver
  attachScreenSaverEventListeners();

  if(!screenSaver.initiated) {

    //* set screensaver options
    screenSaver.options = {

       timeout: options.timeout || 5000, //* default timer to start screensaver is 10 minutes

        width: options.width || 25,   //* default width is 25rem

        height: options.height || 25, //* default height is 25rem

        exitTimeout: options.exitTimeout || null, //* default timer to exit screensaver is disabled

    }

    //* create elements
    var overlay = document.createElement("div");

    overlay.setAttribute('class', 'screensaver-overlay');

    document.body.appendChild(overlay);

    var createBadge = document.createElement("div");

    createBadge.setAttribute('id', 'saver-badge');

    document.body.appendChild(createBadge);

    createBadge.style.width = screenSaver.options.width + 'rem';

     createBadge.style.height = screenSaver.options.height + 'rem';

  }

  document.getElementsByTagName("body")[0].classList.remove('screensaver');

  screenSaver.initiated = true;

  screenSaver.setTimeoutValue = screenSaver.options.timeout; 

  screenSaver.setTimeoutExit = screenSaver.options.timeoutExit; 

  screenSaver.setTimeout = null; //* clear timeout

  screenSaver.inProgress = false;

  screenSaver.timerStarted = false;

  clearTimeout(screenSaver.setTimeout);

  screenSaver.setTimeout = setTimeout(function() {

    document.getElementsByTagName("body")[0].classList.add('screensaver');

      screenSaver.inProgress = true;

      var saverBadge = document.getElementById("saver-badge");

      clearInterval(screenSaver.setInterval); //* clear badge display interval

      screenSaver.setInterval = null;

      //* get dimensions in em
      var windowHeight = window.outerHeight / parseFloat(window.getComputedStyle(document.getElementsByTagName("body")[0], null).getPropertyValue('font-size'));

      var windowWidth = window.outerWidth / parseFloat(window.getComputedStyle(document.getElementsByTagName("body")[0], null).getPropertyValue('font-size'));

      screenSaver.setInterval = setInterval(function() {

        if (screenSaver.inProgress === true) {

          saverBadge.classList.remove('visible');

          setTimeout(function() {

            saverBadge.offsetWidth = saverBadge.offsetWidth;

            saverBadge.classList.add('visible');

          },1);

          var saverTopValue = Math.floor(Math.random() * windowHeight) - screenSaver.options.width;

          var saverLeftValue = Math.floor(Math.random() * windowWidth) - screenSaver.options.height;

          if (saverTopValue <= 0) { //* make sure the badge doesn't go off the screen

            saverTopValue = saverTopValue + 15;

          }

          if (saverLeftValue <= 0) {

            saverLeftValue = saverLeftValue + 15;

          }

          saverBadge.style.top = saverTopValue + 'rem';

          saverBadge.style.left = saverLeftValue + 'rem';

          if(screenSaver.timerStarted === false && screenSaver.options.exitTimeout != null) {

            startScreenSaverTimer();

          }
        }
      }, 6000);

    }, screenSaver.setTimeoutValue);
}

function startScreenSaverTimer() {

  screenSaver.timerStarted = true;

  setTimeout(function() {

    stopScreenSaver();

  }, screenSaver.setTimeoutExit);

}

function stopScreenSaver() {

  startScreenSaver();

  clearInterval(screenSaver.setInterval);

  document.getElementsByTagName("body")[0].classList.remove('screensaver');

  screenSaver.timerStarted = false;

}

function attachScreenSaverEventListeners() {

  var events = ['touchstart', 'mousedown', 'mousemove', 'touchmove', 'keypress', 'scroll'];

  var resetScreenSaver = function(e) {

    if (screenSaver.inProgress) {

      e.stopPropagation();

      e.preventDefault();

    }

    clearTimeout(screenSaver.setTimeout);

    clearInterval(screenSaver.setInterval);

    document.getElementsByTagName("body")[0].classList.remove('screensaver');

    startScreenSaver();

  }

  var checkClick = function(e) {

    if (screenSaver.inProgress) {

      startScreenSaver();

    }

  }

  var bindEvents = function(eventName) {

    document.addEventListener(eventName, screenSaver.initialize);

    //* bind click as fallback for touchstart and mousedown
    document.addEventListener('click', checkClick);

  }

  var unbindEvents = function(eventName) {

    document.removeEventListener(eventName, screenSaver.initialize);

  }

}    

    </script>


</body>

</html>

  var resetScreenSaver = function(e) {

    if (screenSaver.inProgress) {

      e.stopPropagation();

      e.preventDefault();

    }

    clearTimeout(screenSaver.setTimeout);

    clearInterval(screenSaver.setInterval);

    document.getElementsByTagName("body")[0].classList.remove('screensaver');

    startScreenSaver();

  }

  var checkClick = function(e) {

    if (screenSaver.inProgress) {

      startScreenSaver();

    }

  }

  var bindEvents = function(eventName) {

    document.addEventListener(eventName, screenSaver.initialize);

    //* bind click as fallback for touchstart and mousedown
    document.addEventListener('click', checkClick);

  }

  var unbindEvents = function(eventName) {

    document.removeEventListener(eventName, screenSaver.initialize);

  }

  for (var i=0;i<events.length;i++) {

    bindEvents(events[i]);

  }

}

items.title: post json from android app to node js
items.body:
I looked around but I have not found a suitable solution yet. I need to send some information to be integrated into my MySQL database on a node/express js host. I was thinking of sending this information through a JSON with the POST HTTP method. This is how I create my JSON:

JSONObject json = new JSONObject();
 try {
    json.put("id", idU);
    json.put("name","xxx");
 } catch (JSONException e) {
   e.printStackTrace();
 }

My JSON is so structured (or at least it should):

{"id":"xx","name":"xyz"}

I noticed that by reading the other APIs I have for database read queries the JSON displayed is of the form:

[{"xx":"11","yy":"33",....}]

I then tried to add the square brackets to my string but it does not improve ("[" and "]").

The connection between the app and the database on the server works because I can retrieve the information from my database. I wrote javascript APIs to perform these functions, while for the GET everything works correctly, POST gives me some problems. I receive this response message from the server in my app (404 Not Found) through the following codes:

String.valueOf(httpURLConnection.getResponseCode())
httpURLConnection.getResponseMessage()

this is my javascript:

exports.postchk = function(req, res){

  var input = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(req.body));  
  req.getConnection(function(err,connection){
    if(err){
      console.log("Error Selecting : %s ",err );
    }else{
      var query = connection.query('UPDATE user SET name = ? WHERE id = ?',[input.name,input.id],function(err,rows)
      {       
        if(err){
          res.send(JSON.stringify({"error":error,"response": null}));
        }else{
          res.send(JSON.stringify({"input":input, "name":input.name, "chk":input.checkin, "response": rows}));
        }

      });
    }       
  }); 
};

The API should work seamlessly as I can see the following message if I log in through the URL:

{"input":{},"response":{"fieldCount":0,"affectedRows":0,"insertId":0,"serverStatus":2,"warningCount":0,"message":"(Rows matched: 0 Changed: 0 Warnings: 0","protocol41":true,"changedRows":0}}

On my console server, I get the HTTP 304 code.

If I try to print the contents of the input variable (req.body) both in the android log and in the console of my server I get that it is empty.

Below is the code I use to make the connection and the POST method to the server:

public void writer(JSONObject json){
  final JSONObject js = json;
    new Thread() {
        public void run() {
            try {
                Authenticator.setDefault(new Authenticator(){
                    protected PasswordAuthentication getPasswordAuthentication() {
                        return new PasswordAuthentication(user,password.toCharArray());
                    }});
                HttpURLConnection httpURLConnection = (HttpURLConnection) new URL(chk_url).openConnection();
                httpURLConnection.setUseCaches(false);
                httpURLConnection.setRequestMethod("POST");
                httpURLConnection.setDoOutput(true);
                httpURLConnection.setDoInput(true);
                httpURLConnection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type", "application/json");
                httpURLConnection.setRequestProperty("Accept", "application/json");
                httpURLConnection.connect();
                OutputStream os = httpURLConnection.getOutputStream();
                BufferedWriter writer = new BufferedWriter(
                        new OutputStreamWriter(os, "UTF-8"));
                writer.write(js.toString());
                writer.flush();
                writer.close();
                os.close();
            } catch (final MalformedURLException e) {
                e.printStackTrace();
                VisualUserActivity.this.runOnUiThread(new Runnable()
                {
                    public void run()
                    {
                        Toast.makeText(VisualUserActivity.this, "Error", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show();
                    }
                });
            } catch (final IOException e) {
                e.printStackTrace();
                VisualUserActivity.this.runOnUiThread(new Runnable()
                {
                    public void run()
                    {
                        Toast.makeText(VisualUserActivity.this, "Error", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show();
                    }
                });
            }
        }
    }.start();
}

I also tried with this variant, but the result is the same.

DataOutputStream os = new DataOutputStream(httpURLConnection.getOutputStream());
os.writeBytes(js.toString());
os.flush();
os.close();

I understand that the input to the API is null, but I do not understand if it is a formatting error of the JSON or if it depends on something in the connection that fails to send it. Thanks in advance for your help.

items.title: raster calculation with condition of each cell by layers in R
items.body:
I have stack raster dataset with several layers, however, I want to calculate the sum of each cell with for different layer selection, and finally generate a new layer, anyone has some good suggestion by using calc or overlay or some other raster calculation in R? I can do by loops and make the calculation, but it will consume many times when I have many layers, and also use many of the storage, my script as follows,

## library(raster)
make_calc <- function(rr, start, end) {
  rr <- as.array(rr)
  start <- as.array(start)
  end <- as.array(end)
  dms <- dim(raster)
  tmp <- array(NA, dim = dms[1:2])
  for (i in 1:dms[1]) {
    for (j in 1:dms[2]) {
      tmp[i,j] <- sum(raster[i,j,start[i,j,1]:end[i,j,1]], na.rm = TRUE)
    }
  }
  return(tmp)
}

rr <- raster(res = 10)
rr[] <- 1
rr <- stack(rr, rr, rr, rr)
start <- raster(res = 10)

items.title: Interfaces vs struct methods
items.body:
I have code with interface:

package main

import (
    "math"
    "fmt"
)

type Circle struct {
    x, y, r float64
}

type Rectangle struct {
    x1, y1, x2, y2 float64
}

type Figure interface {
    Area() float64
}

func (c *Circle) Area() float64 {
    return math.Pi * c.r * c.r
}

func (r *Rectangle) Area() float64 {
    return math.Abs(r.x2 - r.x1) * math.Abs(r.y2 - r.y1)
}

func main() {
    figures := make([]Figure, 0)
    figures = append(figures, &Circle{0, 0, 10})
    figures = append(figures, &Rectangle{0, 0, 10, 20})
    for _, figure := range figures {
        fmt.Print(figure.Area(), "\n")
    }
}

output:

314.159265
200

and code with only methods for my struct:

package main

import (
    "math"
    "fmt"
)

type Circle struct {
    x, y, r float64
}

type Rectangle struct {
    x1, y1, x2, y2 float64
}

func (c *Circle) Area() float64 {
    return math.Pi * c.r * c.r
}

// Реализация интерфейса Figure для Rectangular.
func (r *Rectangle) Area() float64 {
    return math.Abs(r.x2 - r.x1) * math.Abs(r.y2 - r.y1)
}

func main() {
    c := Circle{0,0,10}
    r := Rectangle{0,0,10,20}

    fmt.Print(c.Area(), "\n")
    fmt.Print(r.Area(), "\n")
}

and the same output:

314.1592653589793
200

When I use interface I have extra code in the form of interfaces declaration. If the interfaces perfectly implement polymorphism in Go, why then the methods of structures? What plus from interfaces, where is the difference? May be my example not good. Thank you!

items.body:
Please see the code below:

 public class Program
    {

        {

            Guid chesnutID = Guid.NewGuid();

            IProduct concor1 = new Concor(concorID);
            IProduct concor2 = new Concor(concorID);
            IProduct chestnut1 = new Concor(chesnutID);
            IProduct chestnut2 = new Concor(chesnutID);

            ISet<IProduct> products = new HashSet<IProduct>();
            products.Add(concor1);
            products.Add(chestnut1);
            products.Add(concor2);
            products.Add(chestnut2);
        }
    }

    public interface IProduct
    {
        //This contains methods that are implemented by the products
    }

    public class Concor : IProduct
    {
        private Guid _id;

        public Concor(Guid id)
        {
            _id = id;
        }

    }

    public class Chestnut : IProduct
    {
        private Guid _id;

        public Chestnut(Guid id)
        {
            _id = id;
        }
    }

After the code runs there are four products added to the HashSet because the HashSet is using referential equality to establish if the products are the same (which I expect). However, I want the HashSet to recognise products as unique by ID. Therefore in the case of the example above; only two should appear in the HashSet. Please note that I cannot override .equals or IEquatable. I have tried making the following changes:

public class Program
    {
        static void Main(string[] args)
        {
            Guid concorID = Guid.NewGuid();
            Guid chesnutID = Guid.NewGuid();

            IProduct concor1 = new Concor(concorID);
            IProduct concor2 = new Concor(concorID);
            IProduct chestnut1 = new Concor(chesnutID);
            IProduct chestnut2 = new Concor(chesnutID);

            IEqualityComparer<IEntity<IProduct>> comparer = new EntityEqualityComparer<IEntity<IProduct>>(); //Error Line 1
            ISet<IProduct> products = new HashSet<IProduct>();
            products.Add(concor1);
            products.Add(chestnut1);
            products.Add(concor2);
            products.Add(chestnut2);
        }
    }

    public interface IProduct: IEntity<IProduct>
    {
        //This contains methods that are implemented by the products
    }

    public class Concor : IProduct, IEntity<IProduct>
    {
        private Guid _id;

        public Concor(Guid id)
        {
            _id = id;
        }

        public bool SameIdentityAs(IProduct other)
        {
            return other != null && _id == other._id; //Error Line 2
        }
    }

    public class Chestnut : IProduct, IEntity<IProduct>
    {
        private Guid _id;

        public Chestnut(Guid id)
        {
            _id = id;
        }

        public bool SameIdentityAs(IProduct other)
        {
            return other != null && _id == other._id; //Error Line 3
        }
    }

    public interface IEntity<T>
    {
        bool SameIdentityAs(T other);
    }

    public class EntityEqualityComparer<T> : IEqualityComparer<T>
        where T : IEntity<T>
    {
        public bool Equals(T entity1, T entity2)
        {
            if (entity1 == null && entity2 == null)
                return true;
            else if (entity1 == null | entity2 == null)
                return false;
            else if (entity1.SameIdentityAs(entity2))
                return true;
            else
                return false;
        }

        public int GetHashCode(T entity1)
        {
            return entity1.GetHashCode();
        }
    }

Can I use the EntityEqualityComparer to ensure that unique products are added to the HashSet? I want to use the SameIdentityAs method to establish if two objects are equal.

I have identified the lines that have errors:

Error Line 1: Error CS0311 The type 'ConsoleApp1.IEntity' cannot be used as type parameter 'T' in the generic type or method 'EntityEqualityComparer'.

Error Line 2 and 3: Error CS1061 'IProduct' does not contain a definition for '_id' and no extension method '_id' accepting a first argument of type 'IProduct' could be found (are you missing a using directive or an assembly reference?)

I attempted to ask this question earlier, however I made a bit of a mess of the code trying to show specific parts to make it easier to understand (so I deleted the question).

In ReactJs, what would be the best way to breakdown the component hierarchy in a multi-page application ? For an example take an application with two columns. Left most column is the side bar and the right most column is for loading different views.

One view flow would be as follows. Side bar contains a link to view a list of products. Once the link is clicked a set of product with brief descriptions would be loaded into the right hand column.

If the user selects a specific product, the a full detailed view of that product would be loaded in the same panel replacing the original list view.

Now does that full detailed view component comes under the product list component as it's loaded by clicking on a product or is it better to keep it as a child component of the main application ?

items.title: Postgresql Closing statement takes a long time
items.body:
In order to add millions of records to a Postgres database with constant memory consumption, I am using a thread pool with several workers as well as a gorp.Transaction.

Per million records, the following code is called from different threads about a hundred times, each time handling a batch of 10000 records or so:

func batchCopy(p importParams) error {
  copy := pq.CopyIn("entity", "startdate", "value", "expirydate", "accountid")
  stmt, err := p.txn.Prepare(copy)
  if err != nil {
    return err
  }

  for _, r := range p.records {
    _, err := stmt.Exec(
        r.startDate,
        r.value,
        r.expiryDate,
        p.accountId)

    if err != nil {
      return err
    }
  }

  if err := stmt.Close(); err != nil {
    return err
  }
  return nil
}

For some reason, I've noticed that the process tends to be very slow with the Prepare and Close calls taking very long.

I then tried to reuse the same statement for all of my calls to batchCopy and close it after all of them are done. In this case, the batchCopy finishes very fast, but when I call stmt.Close() - it takes forever.

Questions:

  • What would be the right way to go about statements? Should I create one per batch or reuse them?
  • What is happening in stmt.Close() and why does it take so long after many calls to stmt.Exec?
